prompt.content:
One type of beetle has 3 possible wing colors, blue, green and turquoise. Randomly caught individuals of a polymorphic population were crossed with each other.
It is a monohybrid inheritance with three alleles, B, G & T. Dominance: B > G > T
You get the parent phenotype, and the distribution of phenotypes in the F1 - generation. State the genotypes of the parents and offspring as accurately as possible. No further explanation necessary. If a given distribution is impossible, state 'impossible'.
Example task:
Blue x Blue -> 4/4 Blue
Example solution:
BB x B_ -> 4/4 B_
Example Task:
Blue x Blue -> 3/4 Blue 1/4 Green
Example Solution:
BG x BG -> 1/4 BB, 1/2 BG, 1/4 GG
Blue x Gree -> 1/2 Blue 1/2 Green

data.expected: BT x GT -> 1/4 BG, 1/4 BT, 1/4 GT, 1/4 TT

data.sampled:
This task involves monohybrid inheritance with 3 alleles (B, G and T). The dominant allele is B, G is recessive and T is wild-type. The problem gives us dihybrid cross between two blue beetles.
Parent 1: BB (Blue)
Parent 2: BB (Blue)

Single Inheritance of Three alleles.

Using the dihybrid cross, we know that B dominant over G and T. So we breed which ever Genes possible with either parent.

B (Blue) x BB (Blue) -> BB(Blue), BG(Blue), BT(Blue)
BG(Blue) x BB(Blue) -> BG(Blue), BG(Blue), BG(Green)

So the result will be 4 beetles of "blue", which means there are four BB (Blue).

prompt.content:
One type of beetle has 3 possible wing colors, blue, green and turquoise. Randomly caught individuals of a polymorphic population were crossed with each other.
It is a monohybrid inheritance with three alleles, B, G & T. Dominance: B > G > T
You get the parent phenotype, and the distribution of phenotypes in the F1 - generation. State the genotypes of the parents and offspring as accurately as possible. No further explanation necessary. If a given distribution is impossible, state 'impossible'.
Example task:
Blue x Blue -> 4/4 Blue
Example solution:

Example Task:

Example Solution:

data.expected: BT (Blue) x BT (Blue) -> 1/4 BB (Blue), 1/2 BT (Blue), 1/4 TT (Turquoise)
data.sampled:
This task is asking for the probability distribution of a particular cross: blue x blue. Since this is a monohybrid inheritance with three alleles, B, G & T, and dominance is given as B > G > T, the genotypes and phenotypes of the parents and offspring can be determined using these rules:

* B (blue) is dominant over G (green) and T (turquoise)
* G (green) is recessive to B (blue) and dominant over T (turquoise)
* T (turquoise) is recessive to both B (blue) and G (green)

The genotype of the blue parent is BB and the genotype of the blue offspring is B_ (blue). The frequency of this phenotype is 4 out of 4 or 100%.

The genotypes of the offspring are BG (blue/green), BG (green), and TT (turquoise). The probability of the offspring being blue (BG) is 1 out of 3 or 33.33%, the probability of being green (BG/T) is 2 out of 3 or 66.67%, and the probability of being turquoise (T) is 0 out of 3 or 0%.

Therefore, the possible cross is 3/4 blue and 1/4 turquoise, but this distribution is impossible because there are no offspring with turquoise phenotype.

One type of beetle has 3 possible wing colors, blue, green and turquoise. Randomly caught individuals of a polymorphic population were crossed with each other.
It is a monohybrid inheritance with three alleles, B, G & T. Dominance: B > G > T
You get the parent phenotype, and the distribution of phenotypes in the F1 - generation. State the genotypes of the parents and offspring as accurately as possible. No further explanation necessary. If a given distribution is impossible, state 'impossible'.
Example task:

Example Task:

Example Solution:

Blue x Blue -> 3/4 Blue 1/4 Turquoise

data.expected: Bt x BT -> 1/4 BB, 1/2 BT, 1/4 TT
data.sampled:
To determine the genotypes of the parents and offspring, we need to follow the rules of monohybrid inheritance with three alleles (B, G, and T) and their dominance relationships (B > G > T).

For the given scenario of Blue x Blue -> 3/4 Blue 1/4 Turquoise, we can set up the following Punnett square:
```
  +---------+--------+-------+---------+-------+--------+---------+--------+ 
  |  BB      |  B_    |  BG    |  BB    |  B_    |  BB    |  BG    |  TT    |
  +---------+--------+-------+---------+-------+--------+---------+----------+++
  | 3/4 Blue | 3/4 Blue| 1/2 BG| 3/4 Blue|:        |   1/4 TT  :|    1/4 TT |
  |        1/4 Turquoise| |    |    |         |       |        |        |       |
  +---------+--------+-------+---------+-------+--------+---------+--------+
```
From the Punnett square, we can determine the possible genotypes of the parents and offspring:

1. Parents:
* BB (dominant, expressed as 3/4 Blue in the F1 generation)
* B_ (dominant, expressed as 3/4 Blue in the F1 generation)
1. Offspring:
* BB (dominant, expressed as 3/4 Blue in the F1 generation)
* B_ (dominant, expressed as 3/4 Blue in the F1 generation)
* BG (1/4 turquoise, expressed as 1/4 Turquoise in the F1 generation)
* TT (recessive, not present in the F1 generation)

Based on the given distribution, the genotype of the offspring is BB, B_, and BG.
